demographics.name: Brenda Smith
demographics.supportServices: Prophylactic PEG tube placed pre-treatment. Nutrition, Speech/Swallow Therapy, and Palliative/Pain Service consults obtained and following closely.
demographics.mobility: Ambulatory without assistance, but with baseline dysphagia and treatment-related fatigue. ECOG 1.

diagnosis.location: Left Base of Tongue / Oropharynx (within prior radiation field)
diagnosis.symptomsAtPresentation: Patient presented with a 3-month history of worsening left-sided throat pain, globus sensation, and significant pain with swallowing (odynophagia).
pathologyFindings: Biopsy of Left Base of Tongue (02/20/2025): Moderately differentiated, invasive Squamous Cell Carcinoma. HPV status re-tested and is negative on this recurrence.
Prior Pathology (2015): HPV-positive p16+ SCCa of the Left Tonsil.
diagnosis.relevantHistory: Original Diagnosis (2015): Stage II (T2N1M0) HPV+ SCCa of the Left Tonsil. Treated with definitive IMRT (70 Gy) and concurrent Cisplatin, completed in 2016. Has known late effects from prior RT including severe dry mouth (xerostomia) and neck fibrosis. 30 pack-year smoking history (quit in 2015).
diagnosis.baselineStatus: ECOG 1. Patient has significant baseline xerostomia and dysphagia from prior treatment. Pain from recurrence is managed with oral opioids.

treatmentPlan.targetVolumeSummary: The GTV includes the recurrent tumor seen on PET/MRI. The PTV is a tight margin around the GTV. The plan is highly conformal to deliver a curative re-irradiation dose while respecting the cumulative dose tolerance of previously irradiated critical structures.
treatmentPlan.techniqueSummary: Intensity-Modulated Proton Therapy (IMPT) using pencil beam scanning. Proton therapy is considered mandatory in this re-irradiation setting to deliver a high dose to the recurrence while minimizing additional dose to the spinal cord, brainstem, mandible, and other tissues already treated to tolerance.
treatmentPlan.concurrentChemo: None (deferred due to the high potential for overlapping toxicities in the re-irradiation setting).
medications: Prophylactic PEG tube placed for nutritional support.
Fentanyl patch and short-acting opioids for aggressive pain management.
Magic mouthwash and other topical agents for severe mucositis.
IV fluids for hydration as needed.
therapistAlerts: RE-IRRADIATION CASE: HIGH RISK FOR SEVERE TOXICITY. Cumulative dose limits are critical.
Patient has a PEG tube; ensure it is clean and secure. Patient is likely NPO.
Assess for severe mucositis, pain, and dysphagia daily. This patient will be very uncomfortable.
Daily IGRT is absolutely critical. Any deviation requires physician review.
High risk of soft tissue or bone necrosis. Report any new, non-healing ulcerations or exposed bone.

ctSimulation.setupInstructions: Supine in a custom thermoplastic mask with bite block for reproducibility. Shoulders pulled down with straps.
ctSimulation.immobilization: Custom thermoplastic mask (Head & Neck), bite block.
ctSimulation.referenceMarks: Marks placed on the mask are aligned to room lasers.
ctSimulation.ctNotes: High-resolution, contrast-enhanced CT acquired in treatment position. This scan was fused with the current PET/MRI and, most importantly, the prior planning CT from 2015 to allow for accurate dose accumulation analysis on critical structures.

dosimetry.planStatus: Final - Approved by Dr. Maria Garcia (03/18/2025)
dosimetry.constraints: Spinal Cord Max (Cumulative) < 50 Gy(RBE) (achieved 48.5); Brainstem Max (Cumulative) < 60 Gy(RBE) (achieved 58.1); Mandible Max (Cumulative) < 70 Gy(RBE) (achieved 69.5); Carotid Artery max dose minimized.
dosimetry.planNotes: Proton re-irradiation for recurrent H&N cancer. Plan provides a curative dose to the recurrence while respecting lifetime cumulative dose constraints of critical OARs. This plan would not be achievable with photons. Significant acute toxicity is still expected.

igrtProtocol.alignment: Match to bony anatomy of the skull base and cervical spine.

fractions.instructionsGiven: Reviewed PEG tube care and oral hygiene.
fractions.dailyNotes: First re-irradiation fraction delivered. Setup verified with physician. Patient is mentally prepared for a difficult course.

fractions.instructionsGiven: Reinforced pain medication schedule. Patient is fully reliant on PEG tube for nutrition and hydration.
fractions.dailyNotes: OTV today. Patient experiencing expected severe mucositis. Pain service following closely. Patient is resilient but struggling.

fractions.siteSpecificSideEffects: Grade 3 mucositis persists. Mild skin desquamation.
fractions.instructionsGiven: End-of-treatment instructions provided. Mucositis and pain will take weeks to heal. Continue PEG feeds. Close follow-up with all services is critical.
fractions.dailyNotes: Final re-irradiation fraction delivered. A very challenging course for the patient, who showed incredible fortitude. Now begins the long recovery period.

imagingAndReports.summary: Intensely FDG-avid soft tissue thickening and ulceration at left base of tongue (SUV 13.5). No other sites of disease.

reportDetails.findings: New intensely hypermetabolic focus within the left base of tongue / oropharyngeal region, corresponding to soft tissue thickening and ulceration on CT component (SUV max 13.5). This was not present on prior scans. No abnormal FDG uptake in cervical lymph nodes or distant sites.
reportDetails.impression: Findings highly suspicious for recurrent malignancy in the left base of tongue/oropharynx. No evidence of regional nodal or distant metastatic disease.

imagingAndReports.summary: IMRT 70Gy/35fx completed 2016. DVHs for critical structures obtained.

reportDetails.oarDoses: Spinal Cord Max: 44.5 Gy; Brainstem Max: 52.1 Gy; Mandible (Left) Max: 68.2 Gy; Parotid Gland (Right) Mean: 24 Gy
reportDetails.notes: Patient completed treatment course. Tolerated with expected Grade 3 mucositis, managed supportively.

labResults.notes: Baseline nutritional status adequate prior to PEG placement.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Charles Davis (H&N Surgery)
progressNotes.summary: Patient is 9 years post-CRT for a left tonsil SCCa, now with worsening throat pain. Exam is suspicious for a recurrence at the left base of tongue. PET/MRI confirm this. Biopsy was performed and shows recurrent SCCa. We discussed surgical salvage, which would involve a total laryngectomy and be extremely morbid. She is not a surgical candidate. She will be referred to Radiation and Medical Oncology to discuss re-irradiation options.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Maria Garcia (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Patient with recurrent SCCa in a previously irradiated field. Reviewed case and prior RT records extensively. This is a very high-risk situation. I have strongly recommended proton therapy (IMPT) as the only feasible way to deliver a potentially curative dose while respecting the lifetime tolerance of her spinal cord and brainstem. We discussed the extremely high risk of severe acute toxicity (mucositis, dysphagia requiring PEG) and late toxicity (soft tissue/bone necrosis). The patient and her husband understand these risks and wish to proceed with curative-intent re-irradiation. A prophylactic PEG tube is mandatory.

progressNotes.author: Nutrition/Speech Path
progressNotes.summary: PEG tube placed without complication. Patient and husband educated on PEG tube care and feeding schedule. Swallowing exercises reviewed to maintain function as long as possible during treatment.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Maria Garcia (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Patient has completed 15 fx of re-irradiation. As expected, she has developed severe Grade 3 mucositis and is unable to tolerate any PO intake. She is fully reliant on her PEG tube for nutrition and hydration. Pain is being managed aggressively with a Fentanyl patch by the palliative care team. She is fatigued but determined to continue. No signs of necrosis at this time. Continue with close supportive care.
